thread.title: Vladimir Putin's cyber plot to help Jeremy Corbyn | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: Vladimir Putin's cyber plot to help Jeremy Corbyn | Daily Mail Online

author: Gareth Davies For Mailonline
title: Vladimir Putin's cyber plot to help Jeremy Corbyn | Daily Mail Online
text: Share The tweets pulled up Nuttall on his controversial Hillsborough remarks. One message read: 'Ukip's Nuttall lied about "close friends" at Hillsborough. Can this man be trusted?' Another stated he wanted to privatise the NHS while one said his party only supported 12 percent of the population. The network of messages was uncovered by Alex King, a specialist researcher who tracks Russian propaganda on social media. He said the accounts were part of an organised campaign as opposed to individual users with their own agenda, according to the BBC . Mr King said the fact the users use stock pictures as profile images point towards it being a coordinated attack, as well as the fact that they are tweeting memes with multiple hashtags. American intelligence accused Moscow hackers led by Putin (pictured) of helping Donald Trump win the US presidency American intelligence accused Moscow hackers of helping Donald Trump win the US presidency. German Chancellor Angela Merkel, whose country will hold a general election in September, has also voiced fears that Moscow could try to influence the vote through cyberattacks or disinformation. Discussing whether or not the party thinks Putin's next alleged target was Stoke, a Ukip spokesman told the Telegraph : 'I don’t think people take a blind bit of notice. 'I don’t think the good people of Stoke are now avidly watching Russian automated Twitter bots. Bot out Putin. 'We are not Trump, we are not Clinton. The idea that Putin gives a flying rat’s a**e about Paul Nuttall winning in Stoke – I just don’t see it.' United Kingdom Independence Party (UKIP) leader Paul Nuttall reacts as he speaks at the party's spring conference in Bolton, Polls in Stoke open at 7am on Thursday and Mr Nuttall was the bookies' favourite yesterday to take the seat, which was left vacant by the resignation of Labour's Tristram Hunt to take a new job at the Victoria and Albert museum. But by this evening, Labour's Gareth Snell had leapfrogged him to the top spot. Mr Nuttall last week being forced to admit claims on his website that he lost 'close personal friends' in the 1989 disaster were not true. He also failed to condemn Ukip donor Arron Banks for accusing Hillsborough survivors of 'milking' the tragedy. The embattled Ukip leader has angrily denied claims he was not at Hillsborough at all on the day 96 Liverpool fans were killed, insisting there is a smear campaign against him. The full list of the candidates for the Stoke-on-Trent by-election Mohammed Yaqub Akram - Independent
